Executive Summary



PAPCO, Inc. (PAPCO) owns and operates a natural gas liquids recovery facility, the Warren Refrigeration Fractionation  Processing Plant, in Warren, Pennsylvania. The plant is designed to recover liquid products from natural gas via physical separation, dehydration, and refrigeration.  Petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas.   The plant handles and stores process flammables such as methane, ethane, propane, butane, isobutane, pentane and isopentane and heavier components in excess of threshold quantities. PAPCO management is aware of potential hazards posed by processing and storing natural gas and natural gas liquids. Programs are established to prevent accidental releases and train personnel for emergency response in the event of a release.  The Warren plant has no recordable accidents in the past five years.   



PAPCO has considered the impact of a "worst case" accident.  In this case, the A!A?worst caseA!A? would be a complete release from one of the  30,000 gallon product storage tanks (propane or butanes or gasoline), resulting in instantaneous formation of a vapor cloud which ignites and explodes. Using the EPAA!A?s RMP*Comp software ver

sion 1.07, the potential radius of impact, due to the explosion, was calculated to extend 0.4 miles.  Global positioning system (GPS) was utilized to estimate public receptors within a 0.4 mile radius.  The worst case event would affect 67 nearby structures, and it was determined that the nearest public receptor is approximately 0.13 miles from the tank.  A consideration of the 0.4 mile radius is incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning.



PAPCO implements safety programs and procedures designed to prevent and mitigate catastrophic releases. Operation, maintenance, training, and inspection procedures are being implemented.  In addition, PAPCO has coordinated with local emergency responders, including the Warren Fire and Rescue Department, Clarendon Fire Department, Warren County Sheriff Department, Warren Police Department and the Warren Emergency Management.  Warren Plant personnel and responders have been given an Emergency Response Plan information. 



With these objectives in mind, this Risk Management Plan is developed to provide information about our management of risks associated with natural gas processing and liquids recovery.  We stress our commitment to ensuring a safe operation for our employees, our visitors, and our community.

2.3 Alternative Release Scenario Analyses - A!A?68.28



Gaseous Release from Process Piping:



Instead of assuming release of the entire contents of a vessel containing a flammable gas, Papco decided to consider a more likely scenario such as release from a hole in a vessel or pipe. To estimate the hole , Papco assumes, for ex

ample, the hole  that would result from shearing off a valve or pipe from a process line containing a regulated substance. To estimate the gas leak, the following simplified equation was used to estimate a release rate based on hole , pipe pressure, and the properties of the gas. This equation applies to choked flow, or maximum gas flow rate. Choked flow generally would be expected for gases under pressure.



QR = HA x Pt x 1/A!A?Tt x GF 



To summarize, a pipe containing methane gas is broken.  Methane gas was chosen due to the fact that it has the highest heat of combustion of any element in the process stream.  The release rate was estimated from the above equation. We estimate that the broken pipe would leave a hole with an area (HA) of 6 square inches. The temperature inside the pipe (T, absolute temperature, Kelvin) is 282 K, the air temperature is assumed to be 25 degrees C, and the square root of the temperature T is 16.8. The pressure in the pipe (P) is approximately 465 pounds per square inch absolute (psia). From Exhibit C-2, Appendix C, of EPA 550-B-99-009, the gas factor (GF) for methane is 14. Therefore, the release rate (QR) is:

2,279 lb/min.  The gas is assumed to leak for a maximum of 10 minutes yielding 22,790 lb methane gas released.  Methane gas was chosen to represent the alternative worst case scenario because it has the highest heat of combustion of any element in the process stream.  



In the alternative release analyses, it was assumed that the vapor cloud was released and ignited, resulting in a vapor cloud fire (VCF).  The results and input parameters follow.

2.3.1 Defining Offsite Impacts - A!A?68.30 



According to the model, offsite impacts will be limited to a 0.4 mile radius for a VCE and 0.1 mile radius for a VCF.  



Within the 0.4 mile radius of the facility, there are 67 residences.  The total population within the 0.4 mile radius is estimated to be 168 residents at any given time.   



There are no public receptors such as schools, hospitals, prisons, public recreational areas, arenas, or major commercial developments within the affected area.  There is an industrial facility approximately 0.1 miles to the southwest. 



There are no environmental receptors or natural areas such as national or state parks; forests or monuments; officially-designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas; or Federal wilderness areas within the affected area. 



2.4 Passive Mitigation



There are no structures that can contain and mitigate the worst-case release scenario.

2.6 Review and Update - A!A?68.36



PAPCO will review and update the offsite consequence analyses at least once every five years.  If changes in processes, quantities stored or handled, or any other aspect of the stationary source might reasonably be expected to increase or decrease the worst-case distance to the endpoint by a factor of two or more, PAPCO will complete a revised analysis within six months of the change and submit a revised Risk Management Plan.



2.7 Five Year Accident History - A!A?68.42



PAPCO has not recorded any accidents that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage, within the last five years.







3.0 PREVENTION PROGRAM 



3.1 Introduction



The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Warr

ations.  PAPCO also assures that recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and resolutions are documented.  PAPCO developed a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed.  PAPCO has communicated the actions to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

The process hazard analysis will be updated and revalidated every 5 years, in accordance with CFR 1910.119(e), to assure consistency with the current process.  All MOC (Management of Change) items will be reviewed at the time of re-evaluation to ensure all process changes are evaluated for hazards and hazard controls.  The updates or revalidations for each process, and the documented resolution of recommendations, will be kept for the life of the process.

3.4 Operating Procedures - A!A?68.69

PAPCO is developing and implementing written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety information.  The following elements are being addressed in the operating procedures:

(1) Steps for each operating phase:

(2) Initial startup;

(3) Normal operations;

(4) Temporary operations;

(5) Emergency shutdown including the conditions under which emergency shutdown is required, and the assignment of shutdown responsibility to qualified operators to ensure that emergency shutdown is executed in a safe and timely manner.

(6) Emergency operations;

(7) Normal shutdown; and,

(8) Startup following a turnaround, or after an emergency shutdown.

(9) Operating limits:

(i) Consequences of deviation; and

(ii) Steps required to correct or avoid deviation.

(10) Safety and health considerations:

(i) Properties of, and hazards presented by, the chemicals used in the process;

(ii) Precautions necessary to prevent exposure, including engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipmen

t;

(iii) Control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs;

(iv) Quality control for raw materials and control of hazardous chemical inventory levels; and,

(v) Any special or unique hazards.

(11) Safety systems and their functions.

Operating procedures will be readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain a process.  The operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and changes to stationary sources. PAPCO will certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate.

PAPCO has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control over entrance into a stationary source by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to PAPCO employees and contractor employees.

3.5 Training - A!A?68.71

Each employee presently involved in operating a process, and each employee before being involved in operating a newly assigned process, is trained in an overview of the process and operating procedures as specified in A!A?68.69.  The training includes emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.

Refresher training will be provided every three years, and more often if necessary, to each employee involved in operating a process to assure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process. PAPCO, in consultation with the employees involved in operating the process, shall determine the appropriate frequency of refresher training.

PAPCO will ascertain documentation that each employee involved in operating a process has received an

r test performed, and results of the inspection or test will be documented.

PAPCO corrects deficiencies in equipment that are outside acceptable limits (defined by the process safety information in A!A?68.65) before further use or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to assure safe operation.

In the construction of new plants and equipment, PAPCO assures that fabricated equipment is suitable for the process application for which they will be used. Appropriate checks and inspections are performed to assure that equipment is installed properly and consistent with design specifications and the manufacturer's instructions. In addition, PAPCO will ensure that maintenance materials, spare parts and equipment are suitable for the process application for which they will be used.

Management of Change - A!A?68.75   

PAPCO establishes and implements written procedures to manage changes (except for A!A?replacements in kindA!A?) to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures; and, changes to stationary sources that affect a covered process.  The procedures assure that the following considerations are addressed prior to any change:

(1) The technical basis for the proposed change;

(2) Impact of change on safety and health;

(3) Modifications to operating procedures;

(4) Necessary time period for the change; and,

(5) Authorization requirements for the proposed change.

Employees involved in operating a process, maintenance, and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process, shall be informed of, and trained in, the change prior to start-up of the process or affected part of the process.  If a change results in a change in the process safety information required by 40 CFR A!A?68.65 (process safety), such information will be updated accordingly.  If a change results in a change in the operating procedures or practices required by 40 CFR A!A?68.69 (operating procedures), such procedures or practices will be up

dated accordingly.

Pre Start-Up Review - A!A?68.77   

PAPCO performs pre-startup safety reviews for new stationary sources and modified stationary sources when the modification is significant enough to require a change in process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review confirms that prior to the introduction of regulated substances to a process:

(1) Construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications;

(2) Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;

(3) For new stationary sources, a process hazard analysis has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup; and modified stationary sources meet the requirements contained in management of change, A!A?68.75.

(4) Training of each employee involved in operating a process has been completed.

Compliance Audits - A!A?68.79   

PAPCO will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of this subpart at least every three years.  PAPCO will also verify that procedures and practices developed under this subpart are adequate and are being followed.

The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  A report of the findings of the audit will be developed. The owner or operator will determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  PAPCO will retain the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports.







Incident Investigation - A!A?68.81   

PAPCO health and safety personnel investigate each incident which resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Incident investigations are initiated as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours following the incident.

In the event of such an incident, an investigation team is established.  The team consists of at least one person knowledgeable in the proces

s involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.

A report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and includes, at a minimum, the following:

(1) Date of incident;

(2) Date investigation began;

(3) A description of the incident;

(4) The factors that contributed to the incident; and,

(5) Any recommendations resulting from the investigation.

PAPCO has established a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions are documented.  In addition, the report is reviewed with all affected personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings.  The review also includes contract employees where applicable.  These incident investigation reports are retained for five years.

Employee Participation - A!A?68.83   

Employee participation is a key element of this program.  PAPCO has developed a written plan of action regarding the implementation of the employee participation.  PAPCO consult swith employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of process hazards analyses and on the development of the other elements of process safety management in this rule.  PAPCO provides to employees and their representatives; access to process hazard analyses, and to all other information required to be developed under this rule.





Hot Work Permit - A!A?68.85 

PAPCO issues a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.  The permit documents fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.352(a) prior to beginning the hot work operations; it indicates the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identifies the object on which hot work is to be performed. The permit is kept on file until completion of the hot work operations. 

Contractors A!A?68.87 

This section applies to contra

ctors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process. It does not apply to contractors providing incidental services which do not influence process safety, such as janitorial work, food and drink services, laundry, delivery or other supply services.

PAPCO develops and implements safe work practices consistent with A!A?68.69(d).  PAPCO controls the entrance, presence, and exit of the contract owner or operator and contract employees in covered process areas.  Contractors are required to sign in and out when entering process areas.  Job Safety Analyses (JSAs) are generated to create awareness of hazards associated with specific tasks.  PAPCO personnel conduct regular informal A!A?tailgate meetingsA!A? in order to cover hazards associated with individual tasks.  In addition, PAPCO has held and will continue to hold formal meetings with contractors to cover safety expectations and obligations of the contract holder.  These activities and requirements allow PAPCO to inform the contract owner or operator of the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the process. In addition, PAPCO explains the applicable provisions of subpart E (emergency response) of this part.

PAPCO is developing methods that will improve its ability to evaluate contractor safety programs and performance.  PAPCO will ensure the contract owner or operator is fulfilling their obligations.  These obligations include: 

(1) assurance that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job; 

(2)the contract owner or operator shall assure that each contract employee is instructed in the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to his/her job and the process, and the applicable provisions of the emergency action plan.

(3) The contract owner or operator shall document that each contract employee has received and u

nderstood the training required by this section. The contract owner or operator shall prepare a record which contains the identity of the contract employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

(4) The contract owner or operator shall assure that each contract employee follows the safety rules of the stationary source including the safe work practices required by A!A?68.69(d).

(5) The contract owner or operator shall advise the owner or operator of any unique hazards presented by the contract owner or operator's work, or of any hazards found by the contract owner or operator's work.
